Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Written by  Charles Brackett, Billy Wilder & Walter Reisch

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Is there anything I can do for you, monsieur?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: No, no.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Yes, monsieur?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Just looking around.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Comrades, why should we lie to each other? It's wonderful.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Let's be honest. Have we anything like it in Russia?

Speaker: all three
Dialogue: No, no, no.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Can you imagine what the beds would be in a hotel like that?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: They tell me when you ring once the valet comes in; when you ring twice you get the waiter; and do you know what happens when you ring three times? A maid comes in -- a French maid.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Comrades, if we ring nine times... let's go in.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Just a minute -- just a minute -- I have nothing against the idea but I still say let's go back to the Hotel Terminus. Moscow made our reservations there, we are on an official mission, and we have no right to change the orders of our superior.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Where is your courage, Comrade Buljanoff?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Are you the Buljanoff who fought on the barricades? And now you are afraid to take a room with a bath?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: I don't want to go to Siberia.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: I don't want to go to the Hotel Terminus.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: If Lenin were alive he would say, "Buljanoff, Comrade, for once in your life you're in Paris. Don't be a fool. Go in there and ring three times."

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: He wouldn't say that. What he would say is "Buljanoff, you can't afford to live in a cheap hotel. Doesn't the prestige of the Bolsheviks mean anything to you? Do you want to live in a hotel where you press for the hot water and cold water comes and when you press for the cold water nothing comes out at all? Phooey, Buljanoff!"

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: I still say our place is with the common people, but who am I to contradict Lenin? Let's go in.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Are you the manager?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Pardon me for introducing Comrade Iranoff, member of the Russian Board of Trade.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Monsieur.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: This is Comrade Kopalski.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Monsieur.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: I am Comrade Buljanoff.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Monsieur.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: May I ask how much your rooms are?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Well, gentlemen, I'm afraid our rates are rather high.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Why should you be afraid?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I might be able to accommodate you. Is there some more luggage?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Oh, yes, but have you a safe here big enough to hold this?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I'm afraid we have no boxes of that size in our vault, but there is one suite with a private safe...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: That's even better.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: But, gentlemen, I am afraid...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: He's always afraid.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I just wanted to explain. The apartment may suit your convenience but I doubt that it will fit your convictions. It's the Royal Suite.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Royal Suite!  Just a minute.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Now Comrades, I warn you... if it gets out in Moscow that we stay in the Royal Suite we will get into terrible trouble.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: We'll just say we had to take it on account of the safe. That's a perfect excuse. There was no other safe big enough.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Of course, we could take out the pieces and distribute them in three or four boxes in the vault and take a small room. That's an idea, isn't it?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Yes, it's an idea, but who says we have to have an idea?

Speaker: both
Dialogue: That's right... that's right.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Give us the Royal Suite.

Speaker: kopalski's voice
Dialogue: Will you connect me with Mercier... yes, the jeweler...

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: I want to speak with Monsieur Mercier personally... Hello, Monsieur Mercier? This is Kopalski of the Russian Board of Trade. We arrived this morning... Thank you.

Speaker: kopalski's voice
Dialogue: Yes, everything is here. The necklace too. All fourteen pieces... What? No, Monsieur Mercier, the court jewels of the Duchess Swana consisted of fourteen pieces. Why don't you check on that? Naturally, we have all the necessary credentials.

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: Eight Rue de Chalon.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Good morning, Count.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Her Highness is still dressing.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: That's all right.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Hello, Leon!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Good morning, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: It's really a wretched morning... wretched. I can't get myself right. I wanted to look mellow and I look brittle. My face doesn't compose well... all highlights... how can I dim myself down, Leon? Suggest something. I am so bored with this face. I wish I had someone else's face. Whose face would you have if you had your choice? Oh, well, I guess one gets the face one deserves.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Your conversation has one marvelous advantage, Swana. However many questions you ask you never expect an answer.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Don't you find that restful?... Why didn't you come last night?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Darling, I was busy looking out for your interests.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Did you win?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: We can forget horse racing, roulette, the stock market... our worries are over! You remember that platinum watch with the diamond numbers? You will be in a position to give it to me.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: We can be rich if you say the word. I had dinner with the Guizots last night.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Those newspaper people?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You'd be surprised how many nice people dine with the Guizots.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: What a gruesome proof of the power of the press!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now listen, Swana... I sold Monsieur Guizot the idea of publishing your memoirs in the Gazette Parisienne. "The Life and Loves of the Grand Duchess Swana of Russia"!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Oh, Leon!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Sweetheart, we won't have to bother about our future if you are willing to raffle off your past!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Was it for this that I refused to endorse Dr. Bertrand's Mouthwash? I could have made a little fortune by saying that the Vincent Vacuum Cleaner was the only vacuum cleaner ever used by the Romanoffs... and now you want them to smear my life's secrets over the front page of a tabloid?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I understand how you feel, but there is a limit to everything, particularly pride and dignity. They are willing to pay any price! They have a circulation of two million!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Imagine two million clerks and shop girls peeking into my life for a sou! Think of my lovely life being wrapped around cheese and blood sausages! I can see a big grease spot in the midst of my most intimate moments!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, I am the last person to persuade you, but don't do it blindly... if this is your decision, you must be prepared to face the consequences...  I will have to go to work.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: My little Volga boatman! Stop threatening! I don't deserve this.  Are you my little Volga boatman?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now, Swana...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: First tell me, are you my little Volga boatman?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes, I'm your little Volga boatman.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Well... two million readers... I know exactly what they want. Chapter One: "A Childhood behind Golden Bars. Lovely Little Princess Plays with Rasputin's Beard."

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I've got one chapter Guizot thinks is terrific. "Caviar and Blood." Swana escapes over the ice!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: A couple of bloodhounds and we have Uncle Tom's Cabin.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Darling, this would be wonderful! Just once... weren't you attacked by a Bolshevik?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Was I? No... not by a Bolshevik!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Too bad! Brings our price down ten thousand francs!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Count Rakonin asks the privilege of a few words, Your Highness.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Count Rakonin?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: He's a waiter at the Clarence, poor devil. You know him.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Tell him I won't be able to see him for a half an hour.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: The Count says if it could be as soon as possible. It is luncheon time and he is just between courses.

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: Your Highness.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: How do you do, my friend.

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: Your Highness, forgive this intrusion, but...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: What is it, Rakonin? Did you lose your job?

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: No, madame, something of the utmost importance... it concerns your jewels.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: My jewels?!

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: I remember one birthday of His Majesty, our beloved Czar... I had the honor of being on guard at the summer palace... I still see you bending before His Majesty... You wore your diadem and a necklace... your face seemed to be lighted by the jewels.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Why do you bring this up after so many years?

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: They are here!... Your jewels!... Here in Paris!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Alexis! Do you know what you are saying?

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: This morning three Soviet agents arrived. I overheard a telephone conversation with Mercier, the jeweler. Your Highness, they are going to sell them!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Did I hear something about jewels?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Rakonin, bless him, has given me the most amazing news!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: My lawyer...

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: I am sorry... I have to leave.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Thank you so much, my friend. I will get in touch with you.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: ...But they are my jewels! There must be some way of getting them back!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What does he say?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: ...But how can there be a question?... Are you my lawyer or theirs?... All right, I'll let you know!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What did he say?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: It looks pretty hopeless... there may be a chance... that's all... The French Government has recognized Soviet Russia and he doubts that they will risk a war for my poor sake. He might be able to make up some kind of a case but it would cost money, money, money!... That's all they are interested in -- those lawyers!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Darling, calm down. Why do you need a lawyer? Haven't you your little Volga boatman?

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: Very good... superb... excellent... it would be foolish to belittle the quality of the merchandise but your terms are impossible. My counteroffer is the absolute maximum.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: But, Monsieur Mercier...

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I'll let you in on a little secret... we are only undertaking this deal for the prestige involved, and, quite frankly, we are expecting to take a loss.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Capitalistic methods...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: They accumulate millions by taking loss after loss.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Hello... this is Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski... Who?... Count d'Algout?... No, no... it must be a mistake... we can't be disturbed.

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: I assure you no one else could meet the figure named by my syndicate... at least under the present economic conditions.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We can wait.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Do we give the impression of people who are pressed for money?

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: Yes. Gentlemen... let's put our cards face down. Right now there is a Russian commission in New York trying to sell fifteen Rembrandts. There is another in London mortgaging the oil fields in Baku. You need money and you need it quickly. I think my offer is fair and does not even take advantage of your situation.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Just a minute.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: He's cutting our throat...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: But what can we do?... We have to accept.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Comrades! Comrades! Don't let's give in so quickly. After all we have to uphold the prestige of Russia.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: All right, let's uphold it for another ten minutes.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: We don't want to be disturbed.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: My name is Count d'Algout. I telephoned.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: If you want to see us you must come later.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I just want a word with Monsieur Mercier.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: But you can't...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Monsieur Mercier. May I introduce myself? I am Count Leon d'Algout. I think I had the pleasure of meeting you in your beautiful shop. I was admiring a platinum watch with diamond numbers.

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: Oh, yes, yes...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Glorious, aren't they?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Now, monsieur, you have no right...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I hope you haven't closed this deal, Monsieur Mercier. It might bring you into serious difficulties.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: These jewels are the property of the Duchess Swana of Russia, and were seized illegally by the Soviet Government. I am acting for Her Highness, the Duchess. Here is my power of attorney.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: You know, Monsieur Mercier, this is all non-sense.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: These may have been the jewels of the Duchess Swana, but, like all private property, they were confiscated by the State.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: We'll leave the problem of their ownership to the French courts. Meanwhile I have filed a petition for an injunction to prohibit you from either selling or removing the jewels. Here is a copy.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I thought it my duty to warn you. I would hate to see you get in any trouble, monsieur.

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: Thank you.  Gentlemen, this introduces a new element into our negotiations. Until this claim is completely settled...

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We can call our ambassador.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: I give you my word! They were confiscated legally!

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: Please try to understand my position. I am not with-drawing. My offer stands and as soon as you produce a clear title, approved by the French courts, the deal is settled. Until then, good day.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I hope you will forgive me, Monsieur Mercier.

Speaker: mercier
Dialogue: On the contrary. I consider myself very lucky. Good day.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Good day, monsieur.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, gentlemen... how about a little lunch?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Get out of here!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Don't look so gloomy, gentlemen. All is not lost. You may have a chance.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We may have a chance.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes... a very slim one. I want to be fair. I don't deny that you might make out some kind of a case.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We haven't anything to discuss with you. We'll talk to a lawyer!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: All right -- go ahead... you talk to the lawyer and I'll talk to the judge!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: That won't help you! You can't intimidate us!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Soviet Russia will put all its might behind this case.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: You think because you represent the former Duchess...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: The Duchess...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: The former Duchess!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: In any case, gentlemen, a charming, beautiful, exquisite woman. I warn you, if this case comes to trial it will be before a French court, and when the Duchess takes the stand...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: All right, go ahead, get her on the witness stand! What can she say?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: But how will she look? The fashions this spring are very becoming to her. Gentlemen, the judge will be French, the jury will be French, everybody in that courtroom will be French. Have you ever seen a French court when a beautiful woman sits on the witness stand and lifts her skirt a little? You sit down and pull up your pants and where will it get you?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: I suppose you expect us to hand over the jewels?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, no, no. I am not a highwayman, I'm just a nuisance. All I'm trying to do is make things as difficult as possible.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Not that we are giving in one inch, but tell us... what is in your mind?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, gentlemen, how about my proposition?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: What proposition?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I just said let's have a little lunch.  Room service.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Hey, Sascha! Serge! Misha!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Yes, Leon...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: What is it, my boy?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: About this telegram to Moscow. Why should you bother? I'll write it for you.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Leon... Leonitchka...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Leon, my little boy.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Oh, Leon, you are so good.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What's the name of that Commissar on the Board of Trade?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Razinin.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Razinin, Board of Trade, Moscow.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: You wouldn't like Razinin.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: He's a bad man. Sends people to Siberia!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: We don't like Razinin.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: We like you, Leon -- don't we like Leon?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: How does this strike you? Commissar Razinin, Board of Trade, Moscow. Unexpected situation here. Duchess Swana in Paris claims jewels, and has already brought injunction against sale or removal. After long and careful study we suggest in the interest of our beloved country a fifty-fifty settlement as best solution. Iranoff, Buljanoff, and Kopalski.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: If we say that, Leon... we'll be sent to Siberia!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: And if we have to go to Siberia...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'll send you a muff.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Oh, why are you so good to us?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Take this telegram to the telegraph office at once!

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: Yes, monsieur.

Speaker: lady lavenham
Dialogue: Good afternoon, messieurs, mes Comrades.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: And how is Lord Lavenham?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: ...and little Lady Beatrice?

Speaker: lady lavenham
Dialogue: Very well. Did fortune favor you at the races?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Comme ci, comme ca.

Speaker: lady lavenham
Dialogue: I understand... nothing to write home about.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Who wants to write home about it?

Speaker: lady lavenham
Dialogue: It's just a saying. How about joining us Saturday night for dinner? We're having a few friends.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Are we free, Buljanoff?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Possibly.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: We'll manage.

Speaker: lady lavenham
Dialogue: Then let's say at nine.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Black tie or white tie?

Speaker: lady lavenham
Dialogue: Oh, let's make it white.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Certainly!

Speaker: lady lavenham
Dialogue: Au revoir.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Nice people.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: What is it, Leon?... You can't hurry such things... You must give Moscow a little time... There's nothing we can do about it... why don't you drop in later?... Au revoir...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Misha! Misha!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: A telegram from Moscow! It must have been here all day!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Halt negotiations immediately. Envoy extraordinary arrives Thursday six ten with full power. Your authority cancelled herewith. Razinin.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: It is Thursday!

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: It's six o'clock already!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: I always said it would be Siberia!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: A Special Envoy is coming from Moscow. He'll occupy the Royal Suite. Move our things to the smallest room you've got.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: Yes, monsieur.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Right away... instantly!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: I'm coming!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: This is a fine thing. Maybe we've missed him already.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: How can you find somebody without knowing what he looks like?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: That must be the one!

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Yes, he looks like a comrade!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: No, that's not him...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Positively not!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am looking for Michael Simonovitch Iranoff.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: I am Michael Simonovitch Iranoff.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am Nina Ivanovna Yakushova, Envoy Extraordinary, acting under direct orders of Comrade Commissar Razinin. Present me to your colleagues.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Comrade Buljanoff...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Comrade.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Comrade Kopalski...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Comrade.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: What a charming idea for Moscow to surprise us with a lady comrade.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: If we had known we would have greeted you with flowers.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't make an issue of my womanhood. We are here for work... all of us. Let's not waste time. Shall we go?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Porter!

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Here, please...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: May I have your bags, madame?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: He is a porter. He wants to carry them.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Why?... Why should you carry other people's bags?

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Well... that's my business, madame.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: That's no business... that's a social injustice.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: That depends on the tip.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Allow me, Comrade.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, thank you.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: How are things in Moscow?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Very good. The last mass trials were a great success. There are going to be fewer but better Russians.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: It's a hat, Comrade, a woman's hat.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Tsk, tsk, tsk, how can such a civilization survive which permits women to put things like that on their heads. It won't be long now, Comrades.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: This is the apartment we have reserved for you, Comrade Yakushova. I hope you like it.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Which part of the room is mine?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: You see... it is a little different here. They don't rent rooms in pieces. We had to take the whole suite.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How much does this cost?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Two thousand francs.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: A week?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: A day.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Do you know how much a cow costs, Comrade Iranoff?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: A cow?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Two thousand francs. If I stay here a week I will cost the Russian people seven cows.  Who am I to cost the Russian people seven cows?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: We had to take it on account of the safe.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: For ourselves... we are much happier now since we moved to a little room next to the servants' quarters.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am ashamed to put the picture of Lenin in a room like this.  Comrades, your telegram was received with great disfavor in Moscow.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We did our best, Comrade.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I hope so for your sake.  Let us examine the case. What does the lawyer say?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Which lawyer?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You didn't get legal advice?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: We didn't want to get mixed up with lawyers. They are very expensive here. If you just say hello to a lawyer... well, there goes another cow.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We dealt directly with the representative of the Grand Duchess. I am sure if we call him he will give you a very clear picture.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I will not repeat your mistake. I will have no dealings with the Grand Duchess nor her representative.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Comrade Buljanoff...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Yes, Comrade?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Do you spell Buljanoff with one or two f's?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: With two f's, if you please.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You were entrusted with more than a mere sale of jewelry. Why are we peddling our precious possessions to the world at this time? Our next year's crop is in danger and you know it. Unless we can get foreign currency to buy tractors there will not be enough bread for our people. And you three comrades...

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We did it with the best intentions...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: We cannot feed the Russian people on your intentions. Fifty per cent to a so-called Duchess!... Half of every loaf of bread to our enemy! Comrade Kopalski, go at once to our Embassy and get the address of the best lawyer in Paris.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Yes, Comrade.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You, Comrade Iranoff, go to the Public Library and get me the section of the Civil Code on property.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Is there anything I can do, Comrade?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You might get me an accurate map of Paris. I want to use my spare time to inspect the public utilities and make a study of all outstanding technical achievements in the city.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Yes, Comrade.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: cigarette girls
Dialogue: Hello! Hello! Cigarettes?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Comrades, you seem to have been smoking a lot.

Speaker: desk clerk
Dialogue: Desk... yes, Monsieur Kopalski...

Speaker: desk clerk
Dialogue: Good evening, madame.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Good evening. She exits out the door.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You, please.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes. Could you give me some information?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Gladly.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How long do we have to wait here?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well -- until the policeman whistles again.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: At what intervals does he whistle?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How many minutes between the first and second whistle?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: That's funny. It's interesting. I never gave it a thought before.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Have you never been caught in a similar situation?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Have I? Do you know when I come to think about it it's staggering. If I add it all up I must have spent years waiting for signals. Imagine! An important part of my life wasted between whistles.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: In other words you don't know.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You're welcome.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Can I help you?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You might hold this for me.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Love to.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Correct me if I am wrong... We are facing north, aren't we?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Facing north... I'd hate to commit myself without my compass... Pardon me... are you an explorer?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No... I am looking for the Eiffel Tower.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Is that thing lost again?... Listen... if you are interested in a view...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am interested in the Eiffel Tower from a technical standpoint.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Technical... I couldn't help you from that angle. You see, a real Parisian only goes to the top of the tower in moments of despair to jump off.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How long does it take a man to land?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now, isn't that too bad! The last time I jumped I forgot to clock it!  Let me see... Eiffel Tower... Your finger, please.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Why do you need my finger?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Bad manners to point with your own... Here... the Eiffel Tower.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: And where are we?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Here... here we are... here you are and here I am... feel it?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am interested only in the shortest distance between these two points. Must you flirt?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I don't have to but I find it natural.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Suppress it.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'll try.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: For my own information would you call your approach toward me typical of the local morale?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Madame, it is that kind of approach which has made Paris what it is.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You are very sure of yourself, aren't you?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Nothing has occurred recently to shake my confidence.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I have heard of the arrogant male in capitalistic society. It is having a superior earning power that makes you like that.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: A Russian! I love Russians! Comrade... I have been fascinated by your Five- Year Plan for the past fifteen years!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Your type will soon be extinct.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Please... can you tell me the exact width of the foundation on which the piers are resting?... and the depth?

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: You don't have to worry. The thing is safe.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am not afraid... I want to know...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I hope you'll forgive me but I thought you'd...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Go ahead.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Four massive piers of masonry are sunk to a depth of forty-six feet on the side of the Seine, and twenty- nine and one-half feet on the other side. The girders of interlaced iron- work which stay the structure have an inclination of fifty-four degrees...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: That's a strange angle.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes, very strange.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: There is an elevator included in the price of admission!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You gave me some very valuable information. Thank you.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: And thank you for getting me up here. I've never seen this before. Beautiful, isn't it?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes, it is.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'm glad I saw it before becoming extinct.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Do not misunderstand me. I do not hold your frivolity against you.  As basic material you might not be bad, but you are the unfortunate product of a doomed culture. I feel sorry for you.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You must admit that this doomed old civilization sparkles... It glitters!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I do not deny its beauty, but it is a waste of electricity.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What a city! There are the Grands Boulevards... blasted out of the heart of the old streets. The Arc de Triomphe... made to greet Napoleon's army. The Opera! And Montmartre... Montparnasse... La Bohme... and now I'll show you the greatest attraction!  What do you see?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I see a house that looks like any other house. What's remarkable about it?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It's not the structure but the spirit which dwells within. There are three rooms and a kitchenette dedicated to hospitality.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: So that is your house?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, let's say I live in it. Such a pleasant place... all kinds of comfort, easy to reach, close to street car, bus, and subway...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Does that mean that you want me to go there?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Please don't misunderstand me...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Then you don't want me to go there.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now I didn't say that either... naturally nothing would please me more.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You might be an interesting subject of study.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I will do my best.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: No... Count d'Algout is still out. Yes, as soon as he returns I'll tell him. Yes... I'll tell him Monsieur Buljanoff.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Good evening, Gaston.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Good evening, Monsieur.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Is this what you call the "butler"?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: This man is horribly old. You should not make him work.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: He takes good care of that.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: He looks sad. Do you whip him?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No, though the mere thought makes my mouth water.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: The day will come when you will be free. Go to bed, little father. We want to be alone.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Count d'Algout, there have been several telephone...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Go to bed.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, may I offer you a drink, or how about something to eat?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thank you. I've had all the calories necessary for today.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: What do we do now?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: We take off our hat and coat.  Well... we don't smile. How about some music?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Is that customary?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It helps. It has ever since King David wooed Bathsheba with the harp. As I am not so fortunate as to have my harp at hand, I shall turn on the radio.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I should say this room is eighteen by twenty-five.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Not too big and not too small. What I'd call the typical room of an average man. Or shall we say a little above average. Now if there are any special aspects you wish to study I have nothing to conceal. Just look around. That's my desk. Those are my books, and here am I. Where shall we begin?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I will start with you.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: That's great. I'm thirty-five years old. Just over six feet tall. I weigh a hundred and eighty-two pounds stripped.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: And what is your profession?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Keeping my body fit, keeping my mind alert, keeping my landlord appeased. That's a full-time job.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: And what do you do for mankind?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: For mankind not a thing -- for womankind the record is not quite so bleak.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You are something we do not have in Russia.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Thank you. Thank you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: That is why I believe in the future of my country.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I begin to believe in it myself since I've met you. I still don't know what to make of it. It confuses me, it frightens me a little, but it fascinates me, Ninotchka.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You pronounce it incorrectly. Ni- notchka.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ni-notchka.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: That is correct.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ninotchka, do you like me just a little bit?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Your general appearance is not distasteful.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Look at me. The whites of your eyes are clear. Your cornea is excellent.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Your cornea is terrific. Tell me -- you're so expert on things -- can it be that I'm falling in love with you?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You are bringing in wrong values. Love is a romantic designation for a most ordinary biological, or shall we say chemical, process. A lot of nonsense is talked and written about it.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, I see. What do you use instead?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I acknowledge the existence of a natural impulse common to all.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What can I possibly do to encourage such an impulse in you?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You don't have to do a thing. Chemically we are already quite sympathetic.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You're the most improbable creature I've ever met in my life, Ninotchka, Ninotchka...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You repeat yourself.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'd like to say it a thousand times.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't do it, please.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'm at a loss, Ninotchka. You must forgive me if I appear a little old- fashioned. After all, I'm just a poor bourgeois.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It's never too late to change. I used to belong to the petty bourgeoisie myself. My father and mother wanted me to stay and work on the farm, but I preferred the bayonet.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: The bayonet? Did you really?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I was wounded before Warsaw.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Wounded? How?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I was a sergeant in the Third Cavalry Brigade. Would you like to see my wound?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Tsk, tsk, tsk.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: A Polish lancer. I was sixteen.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Poor Ninotchka. Poor, poor Ninotchka.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't pity me. Pity the Polish lancer. After all, I'm alive.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What kind of a girl are you, anyway?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Just what you see. A tiny cog in the great wheel of evolution.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You're the most adorable cog I ever saw in my life. Ninotchka, Cogitska, let me confess something. Never did I dream I could feel like this toward a sergeant.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Do you hear that?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It's twelve o'clock.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It's midnight. One half of Paris is making love to the other half. Look at the clock. One hand has met the other hand. They kiss. Isn't that wonderful?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: That's the way a clock works. There's nothing wonderful about it. You merely feel you must put yourself in a romantic mood to add to your exhilaration.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I can't possibly think of a better reason.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It's false sentimentality.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You analyze everything out of existence. You analyze me out of existence. I won't let you. Love is not so simple. Ninotchka, Ninotchka, why do doves bill and coo? Why do snails, coldest of all creatures, circle interminably around each other? Why do moths fly hundreds of miles to find their mates? Why do flowers open their petals? Oh, Ninotchka, Ninotchka, surely you feel some slight symptom of the divine passion... a general warmth in the palms of your hands... a strange heaviness in your limbs... a burning of the lips that is not thirst but a thousand times more tantalizing, more exalting, than thirst?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You are very talkative.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Was that talkative?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, that was restful. Again.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, my barbaric Ninotchka. My impossible, unromantic, statistical...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Glorious, analytical...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: The telephone is ringing.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, let it ring.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: But one of your friends may be in need of you. You must answer.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Hello?... Yes... I'm sorry but I couldn't make it. I ran into a friend from the army... What?... The deal is off! Are you crazy, Buljanoff?...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: ...A special envoy arrived... What?... That sounds better. I'll be glad to see her any time she wants... Oh, she doesn't want to see me? What do you know about that? Why?... Well, I'll get in touch with her myself. What's her name?...  ...I... Oh, Y...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yakushova... Ninotch...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: All right. Thank you.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ninotchka...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I must go.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ninotchka, or shall I say Special Envoy Yakushova...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Let's forget that we ever met.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I have a better suggestion. Let's forget that the telephone ever rang. I never heard that you are Yakushova... you are Ninotchka... my Ninotchka...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I was sent here by my country to fight you.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: All right, fight me, fight me as much as you want, but fight me tomorrow morning! There's nothing sweeter than sharing a secret with a bitter enemy.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: As a representative of Moscow...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Tonight let's not represent anybody but ourselves.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It is out of the question. If you wish to approach me...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You know I want to...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Then do it through my lawyer!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ninotchka, you can't walk out like this... I'm crazy about you, and I thought I'd made an impression on you. You liked the white of my eye.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I must go.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: But, Ninotchka, I held you in my arms. You kissed me!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I kissed the Polish lancer too... before he died.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Good morning, Your Highness.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Good morning, Gaston.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Count d'Algout is still asleep.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: That's all right.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Leon! What in heaven's name...!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Is anything wrong? Are you ill?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Don't tell me the bed has lost its best friend.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I just couldn't sleep. I got up and went back... and then got up again. These last few days... whew!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Darling, you're taking my business affairs far too seriously. Much as I'd love to rob the Bolsheviks of their filthy money, I won't do it at the expense of your health. Particularly as we know we won't get much.  You look so pale... pale but interesting.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Your breakfast, monsieur.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I don't feel like any breakfast.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Nonsense. How can you fight the Reds and make yourself agreeable to the Whites if you don't keep up your strength.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Shall I draw your bath, sir?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Make it ice cold.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Not in your condition.  Afterwards I'll drive you through the Bois. Slowly... in Waltz time.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: A blue shirt, perhaps?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Blue? Let's offset his mood. Find a striped one, and brighten it with a great blaze of tie.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Very well, Your Highness.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Now... here we have two very handsome soft-boiled eggs. Do you suppose hens mind what happens to their eggs? Probably not. They have such unfeeling eyes. We'll put in a great nugget of butter, plenty of pepper and salt... Darling, I haven't seen you for three livelong days... seventy-two hours!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, please, Swana! I don't know whether I'm standing on my head or my heels. Here you are blaming me for neglecting you when I'm trying to concentrate on another woman and can't get near her.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You haven't seen her yet?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No, and believe me I've tried everything! I must have telephoned her a hundred times. I've sent her telegrams, I've sent her flowers... I asked her to dinner... I offered her seats for the Opera...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: That proletarian! In the old days we'd have had her flogged.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: That wouldn't have done any good. Not with her.  She's the most incredible creature I've ever seen.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You just told me you hadn't seen her.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well... er... I caught a glimpse of her when she walked through the lobby.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Imagine the carpets of a self- respecting Parisian hotel dirtied by the boots of a muzhik! What does she look like?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You can't imagine.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: That bad?  Old or young?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Timeless. When she comes into a room you'd think that the Bolsheviks had taken over Paris. She wears her cheap miserable blouse as though it were the latest model by Schiaparelli. What a woman! What a woman! There is a Russian snowstorm in each of her eyes.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You saw all that in one glimpse?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Now, darling, soak in your beautiful pine bath and let Gaston shave you.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Gaston!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We want to talk to Count d'Algout. My name is Kopalski.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Oh... you are the three gentlemen from Moscow?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You may wait.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: That's her.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Imagine! The niece of the Czar opening the door for us.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Once in Petersburg I was driving down the Nevsky Prospect in my cart and Her Highness in her troika swept down from the opposite direction, and when I couldn't make way quick enough she spat in my face.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Now look here, Buljanoff. You never were in Petersburg, you never owned a cart, and she never spat in your face. Who are you trying to impress?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Hello, boys.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Come in, come in.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What's new?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Leon, Leonitchka, she is not going to negotiate! She is going to fight that injunction. She's going to make a precedent of it!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: She says she won't be intimidated by parasites. She called the Duchess a blood-sucking aristocrat and a blackmailer.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What did she say about me?

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: I think she covered you with the parasites.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: And Leonitchka! What she said about us...!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: And they might believe her in Moscow.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: What do you mean they might -- they will!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We don't blame you, Leon, but when we came from Russia we believed in simplicity...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: We avoided luxury and extravagance and today... well, if you were to offer us a glass of champagne, we wouldn't say no.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, boys, I'd like to help you but what can I do? Yesterday I waited six hours in the lobby!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: She doesn't leave her room! She has been locked in for the last two days with lawyers and law books!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: All right, then make an appointment with her so I can see her!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We can't... but you are so ingenious, Leon...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: You found your way to us and we weren't easy to reach, were we?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No, no.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Didn't we put up a strong resistance?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, yes, yes.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: You must help us, Leon... if you don't win her over we're on our way to Siberia!

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Or it might be the firing squad!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Or we can't go back to Russia!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: What's wrong with that?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Yes! We could stay with Leon!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Leon, how would you like to have three lifelong friends?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Boys, boys... don't forget Russia is your mother country. Three sons walking out all at once... that's too much for any mother.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Well, if your mother turns against you, you have to look for someone to adopt you.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Leon! Just a minute...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I'm leaving, dear. I'm lunching at Fouquet's if you can make it, and... Leon, remember, a man should think it over twice before he decides to become a mother.

Speaker: first lawyer
Dialogue: I seem to remember some additional injunctive provision dealing with the property of foreigners residing in France.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You are referring to paragraph 59b, section 25f of the Civil Code.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Page eight hundred twenty-four.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: And do not fail to read the three footnotes. While you are studying it I will eat.  Food please.

Speaker: rakonin
Dialogue: Room service... Just a moment please.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Room service speaking.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Send me a plate of raw carrots and beets, beets predominating on a ratio of sixty-forty... What? There is a strike in the kitchen? Good! Will you assure the strikers of my hearty sympathy in their cause. I hope they will not weaken in their demands and tell them to put no dressing whatsoever on my vegetables... What? You won't serve me either? Now look here, Comrade, I think it is a fine idea to let the capitalists go without luncheon but when you keep food away from me you're weakening the people.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: So! You want to make a strike breaker out of me! I am surprised at you, Comrade! Is it too much for the workers of the world to ask you to walk around the corner for lunch? All I can say to you is take your hammer and sickle and get out of that Royal Suite!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Tsk, tsk, tsk.

Speaker: taxi driver
Dialogue: Where to, madame?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Can you recommend a restaurant?

Speaker: taxi driver
Dialogue: Well, there's Pruniers if you care for seafood. If you want to lunch in the Bois, there's...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Where do you eat?

Speaker: taxi driver
Dialogue: At Pre Mathieu's.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Where is that?

Speaker: taxi driver
Dialogue: It's just a place for workmen.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Where is it?

Speaker: taxi driver
Dialogue: Eight blocks down in the Rue de Poivrel.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: This way, madame. Are you alone? By the window perhaps?  Or a nice little corner table?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: This will do.

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: I think this is the first time you have been to my little place. Your face is new to me. Now, what shall it be?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Raw carrots and beets.

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: Oh, madame! This is a restaurant, not a meadow.

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: Here is what we are offering today. Please make your choice. I am sure you will find something to tempt your appetite.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Why, hello! It certainly is a small world!

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: Well, madame? Shall we start with soup? Fish soup today. I got up at five to fish them from the Seine.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Crayfish soup for me!

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: Then, may I suggest an omelet with mushrooms?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Bring me something simple. I never think about food.

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: But, madame! If you don't think about food what do you think about?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: The future of the common people.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Pardon me for addressing you but you insulted him, you know that. You hurt his feelings. It was just like telling a musician you don't like music. That good old man believes in food as you believe in Karl Marx. You can't go around hurting people, Comrade Yakushova, but maybe you can make it up to him. Do you know how?  By eating everything with relish, by drinking everything with gusto, by having a good time for the first time in your natural life!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I don't like your following me.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I didn't follow you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Then how did you get here?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I always eat here.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: This is a place for workmen.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: But my dear child, I am most at home among working men. I hate the places where you circulate -- the Hotel Clarence... This is my natural element. After all, what are any of us? Workingmen! At least, those of us who are worth our salt. Hyah?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Hyah!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Hyah, fellows!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: They are all my friends. They're a swell bunch!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ah, my friend! I'm happy to see you again!

Speaker: pre mathieu
Dialogue: I'm always glad to meet a new customer, and I hope this first visit will not be your last.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Just an old man. His memory is getting weak.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: What are you after?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Must one always be after something?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Your tactics are useless. My name is neither Buljanoff, Iranoff, nor Kopalski.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, Ninotchka, who wants to talk business. If you win the suit, fine. If we win the suit, better. You do me an injustice.  When we went to my apartment did I have the slightest idea that you had any connection with this deal?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: But you have now, and I know now that you are a man who employs business methods which in Russia would be punished by death.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Death! Death! Always so glum! What about life, Ninotchka! Do Russians never think of life? Of the moment in which we are living? The only moment we really have? Don't take it all so seriously, Ninotchka. Nothing is worth it. Please... relax... I beg you, Sergeant... smile!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Will you smile?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Just smile.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: At what?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: At anything. At the whole ludicrous spectacle of life. At people being pompous and taking themselves seriously and exaggerating their own importance. If you can't find anything else to laugh at you can laugh at you and me.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Because we are an odd couple.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Then you should go back to your table.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No, I can't leave you. I won't. Not yet. Not until I've made you laugh... at least once.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Ha! Ha! Now go back.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: That's not a laugh! I mean a laugh from the heart. Now let's see. I'm going to tell you a funny story. Just a moment... I've got it! Well, it seems there were a couple of Frenchmen who went to America...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: On which boat?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, er... let's drop it. I don't think you would care for that one.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Probably not.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Do you like Scotch stories?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I have never heard one.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Two Scotchmen met on the street... and I don't know the name of the street and it really doesn't matter. Well, anyway, one's name was McIntosh and the other's was McGillicuddy. McIntosh says to McGillicuddy, "Hello, Mr. McGillicuddy," and McGillicuddy says to McIntosh, "Hello, Mr. McIntosh," and then McIntosh says to McGillicuddy, "How is Mrs. McGillicuddy?" and then McGillicuddy says to McIntosh, "How is Mrs. McIntosh?"...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I wish they had never met.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, maybe it's not so good. Let's forget it! How's this? Two men are looking at the moon. One says to the other, "Is it true that a lot of people live on the moon?" "Yes, it is," says the other, "five hundred million." "Whew!" replies the first, "they must get pretty crowded when it's half moon!" Ha! Ha! Ha!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I suppose you don't think that's funny?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It seemed funny to me when I first heard it. Maybe the trouble isn't with the joke. Maybe it's with you!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Maybe you haven't any sense of humor. Well, I'll give you one more chance! Now listen!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: When I heard this joke for the first time I laughed myself sick. Here goes! A man comes into a restaurant and sits down and says, "Waiter! Get me a cup of coffee without cream." After five minutes the waiter comes back and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we're all out of cream, can it be without milk?"

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Not funny, huh?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: So you don't think that's funny? It is funny! Everyone else thinks so! Maybe you didn't get it.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'll tell you that joke again. A man comes into a restaurant. Did you get that?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: He sits down at the table and says to the waiter... Did you get that too?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, so far it isn't funny, but wait. He says to the waiter, "Waiter! Bring me a cup of coffee." So the waiter comes back five minutes later and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we have no coffee."...  A man comes in a restaurant, he sits down, he calls the waiter and he says, "Waiter! Get me a cup of coffee without cream," and five minutes later the waiter comes back and says, "I'm sorry, sir, we have no cream, can it be a glass of milk!"

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ah! You have no sense of humor! That settles it! You have no sense of humor! None! No humor!!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What's funny about this?

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: In addition to the arguments above enumerated for lifting this injunction, we wish to cite the decision of the High Court of Paris, rendered in the case of Princess Marishka against the Government of Montenegro on the fifth day of August, 1897. Comparing the facts in that case with our present set of facts we feel that the Treaty between the Republic of France and the U.S.S.R. should prevail over all...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I'm sorry, gentlemen. The other day I heard such a funny story...  I am sorry. Oh yes... about this injunction...

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: The hearing is set for the twentieth of this month.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: That's two weeks from Thursday...

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: We did our utmost to have it set ahead.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I know, gentlemen, but it is in the hands of the Court. We're helpless, aren't we?

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: Yes. It is unfortunate.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, there's nothing we can do about it. Why get excited?

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: We'll leave these papers here for your further consideration. Au revoir, madame.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Au revoir.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, it means another two weeks in Paris.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Too bad we have to waste all that time.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: I acted on your suggestion and got in touch with the Power and Light authorities. Whenever you want to visit their plants they are open to you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Oh yes, Power and Light. Thank you.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: There's something else which I know will appeal to you. A visit to the Paris sewers. They tell me it is extremely instructive.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Huh?... Why don't you get a haircut, Buljanoff? You all look so wintry, Comrades. And why do we always keep the windows closed?  Isn't it amazing, at home there's still snow and ice and here... Look at the birds. I always felt a little hurt that our swallows deserted us in the winter for capitalistic countries. Now I know why. We have the high ideal but they have the climate... well, Comrades, I don't think I need you any more.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: If there is anything we can do for you...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, not a thing. Would you like to go out?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Have you any money?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, here are fifty francs.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Bring me forty-five back.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What time have you, Gaston?

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Eight forty-two, sir.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I guess it is eight forty-two.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: You seem to be a bit nervous, sir.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I am, Gaston.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: If you will forgive me, ever since you met that Bolshevik lady I've noticed a distinct change in you, sir.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Have you?

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Decidedly. Yesterday I was greatly amazed when I came from the market and found that you had made your bed, sir.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: And Gaston, I was happier all day long. I felt I'd contributed something.

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Well, sir, if you should do it again, which I hope you won't, please remember the order. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ah, there's something poetic about the simple processes of labor. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet... it should be set to music!

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: May I add, sir, that it was with great amazement that I found a copy of Karl Marx's Capital on your night table. That is a socialistic volume which I refuse to so much as dust, sir. I view with alarm, sir, the influence over you of this Bolshevik lady.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I can't follow you, Gaston, isn't it about time that you realized the unfairness of your position? You being my servant? Wouldn't you like to stand on an equal footing with me?

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Isn't there any revolt in you? Sometimes when I order you around don't you feel like kicking me in the pants?

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh, you're a reactionary! Don't you look forward to the day when you can come in here and stand square on your two feet and say, "Hey, you, d'Algout! from now on it's going to be share and share alike"?

Speaker: gaston
Dialogue: Emphatically not, sir. The prospect terrifies me. Now, don't misunderstand me, sir, I don't resent your not paying me for the past two months, but the thought that I should split my bank account with you... that you should take half of my life's savings... that is really too much for me.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Go to bed, little father, go to bed.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I don't look too foolish?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Foolish? If this dress were to walk down the boulevard all by itself I would follow it from one end of Paris to the other, and when I caught up with it I would say, "Just a moment, you charming little dress, I want you to meet Ninotchka... you two were meant for each other." Ninotchka feels more comfortable.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You remember this room?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I've never been here before. I wonder whom you're thinking of. Oh, I know, a girl with a map, figuring out each step, worrying about north and south. Today... now this might shock you... I went up to a taxi and said "Eight Rue du Bois"... and here I am.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You see? Life can be so simple.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: For twelve francs, seventy-five.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Twelve seventy-five from the Clarence? The son-of-a-gun made a detour!...  But he got you here.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It's nine o'clock.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: That's when one half of Paris says to the other half, "What are your plans for this evening, madame?"

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Then could we have some music?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: A wonderful idea! Radio or records?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Not radio. Let's have music that's just for ourselves.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'll play it softly because I have things to tell you about which I can't shout.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, my darling... I... we...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You see I couldn't shout that.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Leon, you know the jokes you told me a few days ago? I wake up in the middle of the night and laugh at them. Now, Leon that's wrong. I know they're not funny, they're silly. They're stupid. And still... I laugh... and when I look at Buljanoff and Iranoff and Kopalski I know they are scoundrels and I should hate them -- then I realize who made them like that, and instead of sending my report to Moscow I tear it up and go down and buy a ridiculous hat... and if this keeps on... am I too talkative?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No... go on.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Leon, I want to tell you something which I thought I never would say, which I thought nobody ever should say, because I thought it didn't exist... and, Leon... I can't say it...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What a gesture for a sergeant.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Leon, I would like to ask you something.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Anything, Ninotchka.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: If you don't want to answer, you needn't. But if you do, you must tell me the truth.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I promise... I swear.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Did you make any change in this room?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: When I was here before I noticed a photograph of a woman on the desk in a wide silver frame. I thought what a waste of silver. That's all that interested me then. Now I would like to know... what happened to the woman?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: The Duchess.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: She's what you call a woman of the world, isn't she?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ninotchka, I love you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I suppose she is very entertaining... It must be lots of fun to be with her, so witty, so glamorous...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Ninotchka, you're jealous.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Leon, don't ever ask me for a picture of myself... I couldn't bear the thought of being shut up in a drawer... I couldn't breathe, I couldn't stand it.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: My darling.

Speaker: headwaiter
Dialogue: Good evening, Your Highness.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Good evening, Louis. You seem to be very crowded tonight. Can you manage a table near the floor?

Speaker: headwaiter
Dialogue: Certainly, Your Highness, this way please... Count d'Algout made the reservation this afternoon.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Count d'Algout...

Speaker: headwaiter
Dialogue: It is only a small table but it will be no trouble to put in some extra chairs.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: No, that's another party.

Speaker: lady
Dialogue: Why don't we go some other place? It's so crowded here.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: No, no! This is glory! At last I'm going to have a look at that female Bolshevik. Can you give us another table?

Speaker: headwaiter
Dialogue: Only one in the rear, I'm afraid.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: That's perfect!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Isn't it divine?

Speaker: another guest
Dialogue: I wouldn't have missed this for the world.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: We must not embarrass little Leon. He is going through enough for my sake. We mustn't add insult to injury

Speaker: headwaiter
Dialogue: Is this satisfactory?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Thank you, Louis.

Speaker: headwaiter
Dialogue: Is it to be dinner, monsieur?

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: Possibly later. We'll just start with champagne.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I'm only afraid that the doorman may spoil our fun. If only he lets her in!

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: Your Highness...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Yes, General Savitzky?

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: I want you to know all the White Russian exiles in Paris are keeping their fingers crossed about the jewels. They are very interested in the case. Swana suspects her countrymen.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Are they indeed? Thank you.

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: They hope the settlement will bring you a fortune.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: General, please... if you hear any rumors that I am a charitable person, will you please kill them at their source?

Speaker: guest
Dialogue: Look! There's Leon!

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: Isn't she something?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Shall we dance, General Savitzky?

Speaker: guest
Dialogue: Are you crazy?

Speaker: another guest
Dialogue: How could you make such a remark?

Speaker: third guest
Dialogue: Swana isn't stupid.

Speaker: marianne
Dialogue: What did I say? I just said "isn't she something?" I didn't say something what.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Is it dry?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Yes, monsieur.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Is that right or do you prefer it sweet?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I wouldn't know. The closest I ever came to champagne was in a newsreel. The wife of some president was throwing it at a battleship.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It's always good luck to launch something with champagne; a battleship... or an evening.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It's funny to look back. I was brought up on goat's milk, I had a ration of vodka in the army, and now champagne.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: From goats to grapes. That's drinking in the right direction.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Ugh... um... oh...  It's good.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: From what I read I thought champagne was a strong drink. It's very delicate. Do people ever get drunk on this?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: There have been cases... but the headache the next morning is worth while -- if you drink it with the right toast.  To us, Ninotchka!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Hello, Leon! What a surprise! You of all people! How are you, my dear?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Hello, Swana. How do you do, General Savitzky?

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: ...isn't he, General Savitzky?

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Is this your new dress suit?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Didn't I tell you Benson and Benson were the tailors for you?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes, Swana, you did.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: It's a dream of beauty. He never takes my word for anything, but I was right, wasn't I?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Am I interrupting?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Not at all. Your Highness, may I present Madame Yakushova?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: And General Savitzky.

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I've some wonderful news for you, Leon. It's about Punchy... do you mind if I sit down?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No... please...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: General, would you mind making my excuses at our table? I'll be back in a few moments.

Speaker: general savitzky
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Well, Leon, we can be proud of our Punchy. He had a triumph at the dog show.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You must have searched weeks before you found anything as divine as Punchy, didn't you, Leon?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Months, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Poor Madame Yakushova... here we are talking in mysteries.... I'm sure you wonder what it's all about.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Not at all.... I understand perfectly, Count d'Algout gave you a dog. You made it very clear, madame.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Dear me... I must be losing my finesse. If I'm not careful I'll be understood by everybody.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: There's a charming crowd here tonight, isn't there?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I'm going, Leon...  but before I leave I must compliment you on your gown, Madame Yakushova. Is that what they're wearing in Moscow this year?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, last year, madame.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Isn't it amazing! One gets a wrong impression of the new Russia.  It must be charming. I'm glad conditions are so improved. I assume this is what the factory workers wear at their dances?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Exactly. You see, it would have been embarrassing for people of my sort to wear low-cut gowns in the old Russia. The lashes of the Cossacks across our backs were not very becoming, and you know how vain women are.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You're absolutely right about the Cossacks. We made an unpardonable mistake when we let them use their knouts. They had such reliable guns.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Will you do me a favor? Stop talking about the good old days.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: A very wise suggestion, Leon. I'm afraid madame and I will never agree.  The only thing we have in common is our lawsuit and that will be decided next week. I understand everything will be over by Thursday. Am I right?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You're right, madame, it will all be over by Thursday.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Good night, Leon.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Good night, Swana.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Now I think I need a glass of champagne.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Quickly, please... tell me one of your funny stories.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: A funny story?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You never finished the one about the two Scotchmen with the names.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, there were two Scotchmen. One was named McIntosh and one was named McGillicuddy. They met on the street.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No, darling. I'll tell you another story, a much better one.  The only thing that will be over on Thursday is the lawsuit. There will be no Thursday for us. Not next week or any week. We won't let it happen. I'll tear it out of the calendar. Is that a good story?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Wonderful -- if one could believe it.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You must, darling.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: To the loveliest story I ever heard.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Shall we dance?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Oo! Darling! Something is the matter.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You just made that trip from goats to grapes a little too fast.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Oh, everything is so wonderful! It's getting farther and farther away!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What, darling?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thursday.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes. Don't worry. Everything will be all right.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Comrades! Comrades!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Darling, darling... please!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I must talk to my brothers!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Shhh! Shhh!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't shush me. I am People! I want to make a speech. I want to overthrow the Duchess!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: But, darling, you can't do that.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Comrades! Good people of France!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now, Ninotchka... please!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: They are all Duchesses here... thousands of Duchesses... and I am going to tell them.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Quite right... yes, yes, yes, but first you're going in that door and you're going to take a little spirits of ammonia and lie down.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No speech?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No speech.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I love you, my little Leonitchka!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: And I adore you, Ninotchua.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Give me a double brandy.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I'm very sorry, Count d'Algout, it is most embarrassing, but the lady you brought with you tonight is spreading communistic propaganda in the powder room.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Give me another double brandy.

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: That kind of propaganda is bad anywhere, but inciting the attendants of a powder room to go on strike.... Well, if she succeeds the consequences will be disastrous.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What can I do about it?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: She has been asked to leave the powder room but without success. We would appreciate if you would see to it yourself.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: You want me to go in there?

Speaker: manager
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir, but I must insist.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Make it a triple brandy. As we

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: All right... you can tell the Duchess... you can tell everybody... they know anyhow... it doesn't make any difference... now get out!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't tell them where we're going, sweetheart.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No. Nobody will find us.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Are we going to build our little house?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes... a little white house.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Not white, darling.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: All right, we'll make it red.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, don't let's have it any color... no color... just a house house... let's form our own party.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Right: Lovers of the world unite!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: And we won't stretch up our arms...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No! No!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: ...and we won't clench our fist...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No! No!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Our salute will be a kiss.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes... a kiss... salute!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I want to confess, darling.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I know... it's the Russian soul.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Everyone wants to confess and if they don't confess they make them confess. I am a traitor. When I kissed you I betrayed the Russian ideal. Leon, I should be stood up against the wall.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Would that make you any happier?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Much happier.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I have paid the penalty. Now let's have some music.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Let's turn on the radio.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Radio! What is radio?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It's a little box that you buy on the installment plan and before you tune it in they tell you they have a new model.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Oh yes, yes. It has a little knob that turns... a little knob... it must be somewhere around here... yes... here... I see...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Here it is!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What shall we get? The news!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, no news. We don't want to know what's happening in the world. We want to be left alone, don't we?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes, sweetheart... all by ourselves.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, then we turn twice to the right and stop at seven...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It's dead.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Well, it has to warm up... you have to give it a chance... just like people... like you and me... first you wanted to fight me and now we belong to the same party... salute!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Now twice to the left and stop at seventeen.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No music.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No, no music.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: There it is... Thursday... you can't rip it out of the week....

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: But I can throw it out of the window.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: There they are... they are terrible things, those jewels....

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: ...but big.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: ...they are the tears of Old Russia... see that stone?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Who cried that one?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Czar Peter gave it to his wife, Catherine the Great. For it he sold ten thousand serfs in the market.

Speaker: leon
