Dialogue: Now, darling, don't get impatient, wait until we are married. You know that worthless butler of mine... that reactionary? Some day when I come home to you I may say, "Darling, I drove Gaston to the market and look what I got from him!"

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: First ten thousand serfs... now just Gaston. It is very encouraging.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Come, sweetheart. Let me put it on you. You will teach these jewels. For the first time they will learn how they can look.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: They belong to the people.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I make you Ninotchka the Great... Duchess of the People!... Grand Duchess of the People!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Is this the wish of the masses?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It is their wish.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thank you, Leon... thank you, masses.  Can I make a speech now?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Comrades! People of the world! The revolution is on the march... I know... wars will wash over us... bombs will fall... all civilization will crumble... but not yet, please... wait, wait... what's the hurry?  We are happy, aren't we, Leon?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: So happy and so tired.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Smile, little father, smile.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: It is tomorrow morning... tomorrow noon, to be exact. I hope you will forgive me. I know it's extremely cruel to waken anyone at such an hour. Don't you recognize me? I am the Duchess Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I know how you feel, my dear. The morning after always does look grim if you happen to be wearing last night's dress. Don't be embarrassed by my presence, though. You couldn't have found anybody more sympathetic to your condition. I remember once in Petrograd when I felt exactly as you do. I had to bow from a balcony to the crowd. My dear, the masses have no understanding of the feelings of a lady before noon. Don't you find that true?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I think we can cut your visit short. Leon is not here.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Of course not, my dear! I didn't come here with any such suspicion. How ridiculous!  Nor did I come here to pick up his hat.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: How stale last night's gaiety looks! It has the taste of a dead cigarette.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: If you were encouraged to come here by our meeting last night I am afraid you misunderstood my attitude.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Don't worry, you were quite rude enough.  Do you mind if I let in a little fresh air and sunshine? I'm sure it will make you feel better and I want you to be at your very best. In full possession of your faculties, at least.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Please come to the point. What is it you want?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I just dropped in to have a little heart-to-heart talk with you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: We have nothing to discuss.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Now there you are completely wrong. If we sit down for a little chat, I'm sure we won't run out of conversation and what's more it won't be dull.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Madame, what is it you people always say, regardless of what you mean... "I am delighted to have you here"? I have not reached that stage of civilization.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: That's all right... I grow on people.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I must ask you to leave.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Leave? That's exactly what I came here to ask you to do. Leave! I don't mean this hotel and I don't mean Paris... I mean France. There's a plane for Moscow at five-forty.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Madame, if you...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Don't worry. I have already made reservations. It's perfect flying weather. They assure me there's a fine tail wind which will sweep you back to Moscow in no time.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: If this is meant to be a joke it is not funny. Or do you still think you're issuing orders from your palace in Petrograd?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: but nothing more -- I warn you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: People cannot be taken away, madame, neither a hundred and sixty million nor one. Not if you have their love. You hadn't. That's why you're not in Russia any longer, and that's why you came here this morning.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Very interesting, my dear, but couldn't you write all that from Moscow? A dissertation on love on Soviet stationery -- would be an amusing paradox.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It is not enough to be witty, madame. People grow tired of being entertained. You made that mistake before. Problems were never solved by bowing from a balcony.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: My dear, you don't know how impressive I could be. Did you ever see me in my regalia with my diadem and all my jewels?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You can't deny we gave the people their money's worth -- almost -- eight tumbling Romanoffs -- eight!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I must insist that you leave.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Not before you agree to use those reservations to Moscow.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: In that case I can only say good-by.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I wouldn't waken Leon. After last night I would say not before three o'clock at the earliest.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I told you to go, madame.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Believe me, Leon can't help you. He doesn't know anything about the jewels... I give you my word... I swear it.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Where are they?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You were very careless with our precious jewels, my dear. They're too expensive a toy for two children to play with.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Where are they?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Don't worry. Fortunately last night a very trustworthy friend kept his eyes open. Perhaps he overstepped his function as a waiter but he fulfilled his duty as a Russian.  I just put this on for sentiment. The rest are absolutely safe. I assure you. But if you feel like notifying the police...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You leave me no choice.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Won't it be rather embarrassing for a Soviet Envoy to disclose the circumstances under which she lost them?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I will have to face the consequences, but so will you. Don't forget they will ask how you got them.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: That's very simple to answer. They were given to me by my mother. They were given to her by her mother, in fact they're mine, you cannot steal what belongs to you!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: They always belonged to the Russian people. They were paid for with their sweat, their blood, their lives and you will give them back!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I told you we had plenty to talk about. Shall we sit down?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Now, let's free ourselves from emotionalism and try to solve the problem in a practical way. Our situation has changed considerably. Before I had only a claim to the jewels. Now I have the jewels.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: In other words moral ideas have no weight with you... all right, then let's deal with legal facts. You know that France has recognized the Soviet.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Unfortunately.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Under Soviet law the jewels belong to the State. France is going to uphold that ownership.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: My lawyer agrees with you. He says France will uphold it in every court, but I will drag you through every court, don't forget that. And when I say it will take two years I am, as always, conservative.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Won't those two years in court be expensive for you? I know that money was no object as long as you could squeeze it from the pockets of the people, but now...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I may run out of money, but you have already run out of bread. Two years is a long time for your comrades to wait.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I see. You have calculated in terms of hunger.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: No, I just wanted to be absolutely impartial. Both of us are faced with two rather uncomfortable years. We can condense these two years to two minutes if you want to accept my proposition. Ninotchka now realizes what she is after.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I am willing to hand over the jewels and sign the necessary papers if you take that five-forty plane to Moscow.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: That's not the way to win him back... not Leon.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: I think I know Leon quite as well as you... possibly a little better. Leave that worry to me. Five-forty leaves you time enough to close the deal with Monsieur Mercier, but naturally you'll be too busy for any farewells. I'll see to it that everything is done in the most expeditious manner and I will also see you to the airport. That's my proposition, Comrade Yakushova.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Oh hello...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Good morning, Leon...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You can leave it here.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: salute!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am sorry to have kept you waiting, madame.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Jacqueline.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Good afternoon, Your Highness.  Madame, I...

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: You didn't find my glove. All right, you're forgiven.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Thank you, Your Highness. Count d'Algout is waiting. He's been here some time.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Leon, darling, how nice! Have you ordered tea or a cocktail?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: No thanks, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Did I act stupidly last night? Should I apologize?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'm the one who should apologize. I should have talked to you before.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Is this, by any chance, going to be a confession?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Oh, no, my little Volga boatman. Have you forgotten our First Commandment: Never Complain -- Never Explain. It has worked so often and so perfectly, don't let's break the rule. And please don't look so guilty, otherwise I'll...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: This time, Swana -- just this once -- I must ask you to listen.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: All right, I'll listen.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I know you hate the obvious but do you mind if, at this moment, I'm not in the least subtle?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Brutal frankness, if you insist.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: There are a hundred ways to approach it, but I feel it can best be said in one simple phrase. I'm in love, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: And I thought it was something serious! How could you frighten me so?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: It must be serious, Swana. Not long ago I'd have considered such a statement rather juvenile and rather middle class. Now I can say it without stammering, without a blush. I'm in love, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Say it over and over again, Leon. Words are a wonderful safety valve, and that's what you need -- because you know it's impossible, don't you?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I have to be simple again, Swana, and you may find it shockingly banal. I've thought it over and I'm willing to take all the consequences, even if it means a complete readjustment of my way of living.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Leon! This has the ugly sound of regeneration.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'm afraid that's what it is.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: The same old trouble, Leon. You're always late. Whether you're taking me to the Opera or calling for me at a beauty shop, you're never on time. And now, when it's a question of your reform -- late again.  By about five minutes.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What is this, Swana?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Knowing the efficiency of the French Air Service I think I can guarantee that Madame Yakushova has already taken off for Moscow.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Has done what?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: She's gone, Leon.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Do you expect me to believe that?

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Here's the telephone. If you call the hotel you will find that you have no seven o'clock appointment.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Imagine, for once in our lives we were in Paris and we never went to the Eiffel Tower.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: They tell me it has a wonderful restaurant on the second floor.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: While you eat, you look at the view.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes, it is an amazing piece of engineering. Still the most remarkable iron structure in the world. Leading to the top there is a staircase of over a thousand steps... but an elevator is included in the price of admission.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Well, everything is in order. I hope you will enjoy your trip to Russia, madame.

Speaker: english lady
Dialogue: Thank you. Oh, by the way, I've heard so many rumors about laundry conditions in Russia. Is it advisable to take one's own towels?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Certainly not, madame. That's only capitalistic propaganda. We change the towel every week.

Speaker: english lady
Dialogue: Oh... thank you.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Yes, please?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Yes... Comrade Cazabine? No, I'm sorry... he hasn't been with us for six months. He was called back to Russia and was investigated. You can get further details from his widow.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Pardon me, I am very interested in what you just said -- you mean when an envoy goes back to Russia -- if they don't like what he has done they put him out of the way?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Not always... look at me... I've been back twice.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Here's my passport.... Please give me a visa. I have to leave for Russia immediately.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Count Leon d'Algout... a count!... a nobleman!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Don't hold that against me... please!

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Why should an aristocrat want to go to Russia?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Business.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: What business?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Private.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: There is no privacy in Russia. This whole thing seems very suspicious. What's the real reason? If you ever want to get into Russia, take my advice... confess!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Confess what?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Are you sympathetic to the former Czaristic government -- the White Russians?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: On the contrary -- I don't want to have anything to do with them.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: You believe in our cause?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Oh... I think it's great! Everyone works -- everyone contributes -- that's what I want to do -- work! I make my own bed -- you can call up my butler! I don't believe in the right of the individual. I like the Bolshevik ideal -- everyone being the same. You just like me -- me just like you -- I use your comb -- you use my toothbrush -- oh, it's a great life.... Please... give me that visa!

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Hello, Leon darling!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: May I introduce myself? I am the Duchess Swana of Russia... another Russia.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now, please, Swana.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Count d'Algout was for several years my personal representative and if it is necessary to sign any affidavit for him I'll be delighted.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now you mustn't miss your appointment with your hair-dresser.

Speaker: swana
Dialogue: Just in case they don't give you your visa to Russia I want you to know that I have signed a contract for my memoirs and rented a lovely little chteau in the Touraine, and if you feel the need of a change...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Thank you, Swana. You are very gracious.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: She must have her little joke.  You're not going to take that seriously.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: The Grand Duchess Swana... active in the White Russian movement?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Believe me, I have no connection with her any longer... I swear I haven't!

Speaker: official
Dialogue: But you had!

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Listen, I want to be absolutely frank with you. I have no business in Moscow.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: I think so too.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I want to see a friend of mine... a very dear friend.... It's a personal matter which has nothing to do with politics or social philosophies.... It's a girl.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: So it's love which drags you to Moscow.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: official
Dialogue: No visa.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I must get into that country of yours!

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Oh no. No visa.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: That's impossible! Nobody has the right.... You can't do that!... If you don't give me that visa...

Speaker: official
Dialogue: You're going to force us... huh?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Now look here... you advertise all over the world that you want people to go into your country and when someone tries to get in, you keep him out!

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Why should I take a chance?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: On what?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: How do I know you don't want to blow up a factory?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What for... why?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Or a tunnel or a bridge...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Suspicions... nothing but suspicions!... That's the trouble with you! If you don't let me in I'll stand in front of this office of yours and warn people to keep away from Russia!... I'll picket your whole country....

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I'll boycott you, that's what I'm going to do!... No more vodka... no more caviar... no more Tchaikovsky... no more borscht.... Wait a minute, I know something better than that...

Speaker: official
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: And you can tell the Kremlin that's just the beginning!

Speaker: official
Dialogue: No visa.

Speaker: radio announcer
Dialogue: March, march, march! Comrades of the World, never has there been such a May Day parade as this! Already for four hours the pavements of Moscow have resounded to the tread of a million boots! Thousands of gun- carriages have thundered past. Thousands of tanks, combined with our mighty air force, have demonstrated to a belligerent neighbor that we are ready and invincible! Now past me marches the great army of our civilians! Men and women of all ages. All servants of the State united in one thought and ideal. Group of Several Units Marching

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Good evening, Anna.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Good evening, Ninotchka.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Aren't you late?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: No, the opera starts an hour later tonight on account of the parade.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Didn't you march?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: They didn't let me. I am in disgrace. Last week at the performance of Carmen I played a sour note. The conductor got so excited he yelled, "There's sabotage in the string section!"

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Too bad... you missed an inspiring day, Anna.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: I know... my heart is sad... but my feet are happy. When all the tanks and guns were roaring over the Red Square I sat here all by myself and played a Beethoven sonata. Not bad at all.  Are you expecting someone?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: A few friends... just a little dinner party.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What are you serving?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: An omelet.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: An omelet! Aren't you living a little above your ration?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, I've saved up two eggs and each of my friends is bringing his own so we'll manage.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: It just goes to prove the theory of our State. If you stand alone it means a boiled egg but if you're true to the collective spirit and stick together you've got an omelet.  That reminds me... have you heard the latest they're telling about the Kremlin?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: That Gurganov, you never know whether he's on his way to the washroom or the Secret Police.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You should be more careful, Anna.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: And you too, Ninotchka.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: About what?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Ever since you have been back from Paris...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I haven't talked to anyone about Paris. I haven't said a word.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: That's just it. It makes people feel queer. I dont' want you to get in any trouble.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I have nothing to hide.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You should. I'll show you.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: When I passed through the laundry yard today I saw all the women huddled around this so I brought it up here. Things like this create a bad feeling. First they didn't know whose it was. Then they saw the Paris label and did it start a commotion! Some said it's what we all ought to wear and others said it's like hanging foreign ideas on our clothesline. It undermines our whole cause.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You know how it is today... all you have to do is wear a pair of silk stockings and they suspect you of counter-revolution.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thank you, Anna. I'll dry it up here when I wash it next. I should hate to see our country endangered by my underwear.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Ninotchka, you know I am your friend, you can trust me.... Did you bring back anything else?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, I left everything in Paris. I just happened to be wearing this.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Tell me... what else did you have?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, a hat...

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What was it like?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It was very silly.... I would be ashamed to wear it here.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: As beautiful as that? What else? Come, tell me.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: An evening gown.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Evening gown?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: A dress you wear in the evening.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: What do you wear in the morning?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: When you get up you put on a negligee, and then you change to a morning frock.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You mean to tell me you wear a different dress for different times of the day?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Now, Ninotchka, you're exaggerating.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No, my dear, it is true. That's how they live in the other world. Here we dress to have our bodies covered... to keep warm....

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: And there?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, sometimes they're not completely covered but... they don't freeze.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: They must have wonderful materials to make a thing like this so soft... something you don't even see.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You feel it, though.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Ninotchka, I wouldn't bring this up if we weren't such good friends.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: What is it, Anna?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: You know I told you that Pavlov and I are going to get married when he comes back from the maneuvers. Would it be asking too much...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You want this?

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Just for the honeymoon.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You can have it for good. It is my wedding present.

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Ninotchka! Ninotchka!

Speaker: anna
Dialogue: Am I going to play that cadenza tonight!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No music.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How are you, you three scoundrels?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Well, we're back home.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: You know what they say -- there's nothing like home.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: That's right... and we might as well face it.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Come, now, you must not talk that way.... You have to adjust yourselves.... We must be brave.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Brave... that's right.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Let's be happy that we're all alive.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: And that's something we owe to Ninotchka.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: If you hadn't given Commissar Razinin such a wonderful report about us, who knows what would have happened?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: I can tell you exactly.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Now let's forget everything except that we're together.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Let's do that.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: It's a real Paris reunion.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: If you close your eyes and listen to our voices we might be in Paris.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Let's not close our eyes. There are many good things to see here too.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: I think I need my glasses.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: A little more tact... look how nicely she's fixed the table -- all for us.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: How nicely you've fixed the table, Ninotchka.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: What a lovely room you have here.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: How many families live here with you?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Only myself and two other girls. One is a cello player in the opera and the other a street-car conductor.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Just three people in a room this size? Whew!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Naturally it's not the Royal Suite...

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Sssh! Once and for all, we're in Moscow!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Just look out of the window and there it is.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: And it's great! Think what it was a few years ago and what it is now.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: She's right...  anyhow let's talk ourselves into it.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Just see how happy the people look... from here....

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Can you blame them?... at least the May Day parade is over.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: That's another thing... it's spring.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: The same spring we had in Paris. Just as good.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Even the swallows are back.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Maybe that's the same swallow we saw in Paris!

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: It is, Ninotchka! It is! He must have been in Paris! You can see it in his whole attitude! He just picked up a crumb of our black bread, shook his head, and dropped it.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: If you asked him why he left France I bet he couldn't name one good reason.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: I should be a swallow! Right now I would be sitting in front of the Caf de Paris picking up flakes of French pastry that would melt in my bill.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Now, comrades... there is something better in life than crumbs of French pastry.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Yes, a good piece of apfel strudel....

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: We will get that... we'll get everything... maybe a little bit later but we'll get it... We must be patient... Finally we got the spring, didn't we? We got the swallows, and you will get your apfel strudel too.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: And if it is too late for you your children will eat it.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Let's forget the future... let's stop being sentimental... let's start that omelet.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: And here's mine.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Comrades... I'm out of the omelet.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't worry... there will be enough.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Come, Ninotchka, let's make it in real Parisian style!

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Let's fill it with confitures, des prunes...

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: ...des raisins de Madre, des framboises...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: ...des petites fraises des bois... de la crme de Bretagne...

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: ...so it blows up that big... what they call an Omelette Surprise!

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: And the surprise is there's nothing in it.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: I know, but if we can't put in all these wonderful things at least let's put in some imagination.  In that one omelet we'll taste the whole of Paris!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Sssh!

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: A man like that... all he has to do is to walk through a room and the omelet drops.

Speaker: vladimir
Dialogue: Comrade Yakushova, here, the postman left a letter for you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: It's from Paris.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: A bill?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: From Leon.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Bad news?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Look for yourselves.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Well, I think it's getting late. Good night, Ninotchka.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Thank you for a wonderful dinner.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Good night, my friends.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: They can't censor our memories, can they?

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Good morning, Comrade.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Good morning, Comrade Commissar. Here is my report on the materials available for trading in the next four months.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Does this include the products of the Far Eastern provinces?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes, it does.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: You mean you have finished the whole investigation?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: That's marvelous.... You must have worked day and night.... Don't you ever sleep?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I need very little sleep. We must be extremely careful what goods we take in exchange. I have already started a survey of our most urgent needs.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Well, Comrade, I am afraid you will have to turn over that work to someone else.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: May I ask why?

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Please... sit down.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Cigarette?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Well, Comrade, have you heard from your friends Kopalski, Buljanoff, and Iranoff?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: I haven't either, but I've heard about them. You must realize it was only on the strength of your Paris report that I sent them to Constantinople; without that I never would have trusted them on a mission as important as the fur deal.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: May I ask what has happened?

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: As soon as our representatives go to a foreign country they seem to lose all sense of balance. If I told you what's going on in Constantinople right now you wouldn't believe it. Those three have been sitting there for six weeks and haven't sold a piece of fur.  "How can the Bolshevik cause gain respect among the Moslems if your three representatives, Buljanoff, Iranoff, and Kopalski, get so drunk that they throw a carpet out of their hotel window and complain to the management that it didn't fly?"

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Oh, they shouldn't do such things. Are you sure this report is correct?

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: It gives details which couldn't be invented. Naturally I want to verify it and that's why I need you.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You want me to go to Constantinople?

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Yes... leaving immediately.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I appreciate the confidence you show in me, but I must ask you to entrust someone else with this mission. I should hate to interrupt my present work. I am positive that my survey is more important than finding out whether three of our comrades have been drinking some extra glasses of champagne.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: That is for me to decide, Comrade Yakushova.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I am sorry, I don't want to overstep my position -- but please... don't send me.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: How can I make myself clear... It is difficult to express but I'd rather not go to foreign countries any more. Please, Comrade... let me stay here... let me finish my work... I am in the rhythm of it now... I don't want to go away. I don't want to be sent into that foreign atmosphere again. It throws one out of gear.... Let me finish my work... I have concentrated everything in it... Please... don't make me go.

Speaker: razinin
Dialogue: Please don't waste my time, Comrade. Do your duty. Good-by.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I will do my best.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: How do you like it, Ninotchka? Isn't it wonderful?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: But Buljanoff, Iranoff, Kopalski...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Now, please, Ninotchka, don't start figuring it out in cows.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You've done it again and I am responsible. How can you forget yourselves this way? You were sent here to make money, not to spend it.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: Buljanoff, she still has those old- fashioned Bolshevik ideas.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: It is high time you got out of Russia.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I must be stern with you.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: That's our old Ninotchka!

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't forget, the day will come when you will have to face Razinin.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Good old Razinin! Is he still alive? How does he manage?

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: But, Comrades...

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: We are not comrades any more... we are friends, Ninotchka.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Imagine, we don't have to whisper any longer.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: We can say whatever we want. We can shout... we can complain... Look...  See? Nobody comes... nobody pays any attention. That's freedom.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: No, that's bad management.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Is it possible to bring you back to reality for a moment? I must have a complete report of your negotiations and a detailed expense account.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Don't ask for it, Ninotchka. There is a Turkish proverb which says, "If something smells bad, why put your nose in it?"

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: And there is a Russian saying: "The cat who has cream on his whiskers had better find good excuses."

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: With our cream situation what it is, it is Russia which should apologize to the cats.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Friends... friends, Buljanoff, Iranoff...

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: ...and Kopalski.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Don't make it difficult for me. This is no more a pleasure trip for me than it is for you.

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: That was our idea when we first came. All we thought we would get out of this trip was a Turkish bath, but... we learned better.

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Ninotchka, we are in the magic East, the country of Aladdin and His Lamp...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: ...Ali Baba and the Forty Thieves... into one single hour you can crowd a thousand and one nights.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: All you have to do is say "open sesame."

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: I don't know how I can get you out of it this time. How will it end? What will happen to you?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Shall we tell her?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: Ninotchka, I hope you'll be our guest.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Guest?

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: We have opened a restaurant...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: ...we have a wonderful electric sign: "Dine With Buljanof, Iranoff, and Kopalski."

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: You mean you are deserting Russia?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Don't call it desertion. Our little restaurant... that is our Russia... the Russia of borscht, the Russia of beef Stroganoff, blinis with sour cream...

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: ...the Russia of piroshki... people will eat and love it.

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: We are not only serving good food, we are serving our country... we are making friends.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Who gave you this idea? What is responsible for all this?

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: There's something in Constantinople... something irresistible....

Speaker: iranoff
Dialogue: ...it is in the air... it may come around the corner as you walk down the street....

Speaker: buljanoff
Dialogue: ...it may step out of a bazaar... it may wait for you in a corridor... it may hide in the shadow of a minaret....

Speaker: kopalski
Dialogue: Right now it's on the balcony.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: They wouldn't let me in so I had to get you out.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: So -- you're behind all this. I should have known.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Trying to keep me away from you! It couldn't be done. Naturally I couldn't go on forever punching passport officials in the nose -- but I found a way, didn't I? Darling, I had to see you. I wrote and wrote but all my letters came back.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: The one I got they wouldn't let me read.  It began, "Ninotchka, my darling," and ended, "Yours, Leon."

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: I won't tell you what came between... I'll prove it. It will take a long time, Ninotchka... at least a lifetime.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: But, Leon, I am only here for a few days.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: If you don't stay with me, I'll have to continue my fight. I'll travel wherever Russian commissions are. I'll turn them all into Buljanoffs, Iranoffs, and Kopalskis. The world will be crowded with Russian restaurants. I'll depopulate Russia. Once you saved your country by going back. This time you can save it by staying here.

Speaker: ninotchka
Dialogue: Well, when it is a choice between my personal interest and the good of my country, how can I waver? No one shall say Ninotchka was a bad Russian.
